Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Thank you Kevin :)

I somehow missed the important information (that each test is run in a
separate instance of class) while reading and using JUnit. Are these tests
run concurrently (in separate threads) or in a single thread ?

If it is a single thread it is probably more comfortable to use a static
variable 'boolean' for  setup() and a static 'int ' to take care that
tearDown() is also run only once at the end of tests. My only contention is
that we should make the tests as easy to understand and code as possible.

Sachin


  -----Original Message-----
  From: Kevin Bourrillion [mailto:kevinb@...]
  Sent: Thursday, February 22, 2001 9:28 AM
  To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
  Subject: RE: [junit] question regarding setup()


  The flag and any variables you want to initialize would need to be static,
since JUnit runs each of your test cases in a separate instance of the
class!

  Unfortunately, this solution still leaves you no way to tear down the
objects when you're done.  TestSetup is probably the better way to go.

  Kevin

    -----Original Message-----
    From: sachin gupta [mailto:sachin@...]
    Sent: Wednesday, February 21, 2001 4:46 PM
    To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    Subject: RE: [junit] question regarding setup()


    One easy way to achieve this is to define a boolean with initial value
true.
    You can set this boolean to false during your first run of setup() and
you
    only execute statements inside setup() if this boolean is true :)

    boolean flag = true;

    public void setup()
    {
          if (flag)
          {
                do setup();
                ....
                ....
                flag = false;
          }
    }

    The basic purpose of the setup() method provided in JUnit is to
initialize
    the variables of testing ground before each  test and that is why it is
    being called by the framework before each test.


    Sachin



    -----Original Message-----
    From: Ryan Ankarberg [mailto:RyanA@...]
    Sent: Thursday, February 22, 2001 8:09 AM
    To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
    Subject: [junit] question regarding setup()


    I was noticing that each time a particular test method within my test
cases
    is called, it in turn calls setup(), each time... How can I go about
having
    it only call setup() once, when the test case is initialized?
